channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Wary of Chinese Espionage, Houston Cancer Center Chose to Fire 3 Scientists
item.media:description: The MD Anderson Cancer Center said it decided to fire three scientists who, among other allegations, failed to disclose international collaborators. Two of them resigned.
item.media:credit: Scott Dalton for The New York Times
item.description: The director of the National Institutes of Health said that 55 similar investigations into possible foreign exploitation of American research are happening nationwide.
item.dc:creator: MIHIR ZAVERI
item.category: University of Texas M D Anderson Cancer Center

item.title: Trilobites: Watch a Flower That Seems to Remember When Pollinators Will Come Calling
item.media:description: A Nasa picta plant, from the family Loasaceae, which contains the subfamily Loasoideae.
item.media:credit: Henning, et al.
item.description: A colorful Peruvian plant dispenses its pollen according to a savvy, memory-based system, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: CARA GIAIMO

item.title: Unbuttoned: Hello, Little Microbe. Doesn’t This Jacket Look Yummy?
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times; Courtesy of PrimaLoft (jacket)
item.description: Now we can trick tiny bugs into eating our clothing. Consumption is finally a good thing.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: ‘I Want What My Male Colleague Has, and That Will Cost a Few Million Dollars’
item.media:description: Beverly Emerson, Ph.D., who worked at the Salk Institute from 1986 to 2017.
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times
item.description: Women at the Salk Institute say they faced a culture of marginalization and hostility. The numbers from other elite scientific institutions suggest they’re not alone.
item.dc:creator: MALLORY PICKETT

item.title: The Lyrids Meteor Shower Will Peak in Night Skies
item.media:description: A shooting star from the Lyrid meteor shower in 2013.
item.media:credit: Jimmy Westlake/NASA
item.description: It can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to see it.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: ‘Partly Alive’: Scientists Revive Cells in Brains From Dead Pigs
item.media:description: Neurons (green), astrocytes (red), and cell nuclei (blue) in the brains of pigs. On left, brain tissue left untreated for 10 hours after death; right, brain tissue subjected to the experiment.
item.media:credit: Stefano G. Daniele and Zvonimir Vrselja, Yale School of Medicine
item.description: In a study that upends assumptions about brain death, researchers brought some cells back to life — or something like it.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Judge Delivers Major Setback to Trump Policy to Increase Coal Mining on Federal Land
item.media:description: Mining operations near Douglas, Wyo. A judge on Friday delivered a setback to a Trump policy to encourage coal mining on federal land.
item.media:credit: Ryan Dorgan/The Casper Star-Tribune, via Associated Press
item.description: The Interior Department acted illegally when it sought to lift an Obama-era moratorium on coal mining on public lands, a court found.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Trilobites: Look What the Cat Dragged In: Parasites
item.media:description: Cats can contract parasites from insects, prey, soil or other animals and can spread them to humans, pets or wildlife.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers found that house cats that roam outdoors were more likely to pick up diseases than indoor cats.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: A Leading Cause for Wrongful Convictions: Experts Overstating Forensic Results
item.media:description: In 1987, a forensic expert testified that there was a less than one in 10,000 chance that these hairs came from the same person. The problem? Those odds were plucked from thin air.
item.media:credit: Virginia Journal of Criminal Law
item.description: These three men spent decades in prison as a result of statistical exaggerations. They were among 150 men and women released from prison after their wrongful convictions were overturned in 2018.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY

item.title: David Thouless, 84, Dies; Nobel Laureate Cast Light on Matter
item.media:description: Dr. Thouless after receiving his Nobel Prize from King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden, right, in December 2016 in Stockholm. He shared it with two other physicists for work that was described as “transformational” in the study of matter.
item.media:credit: Pascal Le Segretain/Getty Images
item.description: Using math to explain strange states of matter, like superconductivity, he had a “transformational” impact on physics, with real-world applications.
item.dc:creator: DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Global Wealth Gap Would Be Smaller Today Without Climate Change, Study Finds
item.media:description: A market in Abuja, the Nigerian capital. Africa’s most populous country, Nigeria would have been 29 percent richer without climate change, a new study has estimated.
item.media:credit: Nwakalor Kenechukwu for The New York Times
item.description: Most of the world’s poor countries are poorer than they would have been had greenhouse gas emissions not altered the climate. In some rich countries, it's the opposite.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: These Otters Are Popular Pets in Asia. That May Be Their Undoing.
item.media:description: Customers play with small-clawed otters in a booth at a cafe in Tokyo. More than a dozen animal cafes in the city now feature otters, the latest in exotic pets.
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.description: Asian small-clawed otters are increasingly popular as novelty pets, particularly in Japan. Now international trade in the species may be banned.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature

item.title: The Giants at the Heart of the Opioid Crisis
item.media:description: The headquarters of McKesson Corporation, the drug distributing giant, in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.description: Civil suits filed by three states accuse pharmaceutical distributors of flooding the country with opioids while devising systems to evade regulators.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Hospitals Stand to Lose Billions Under ‘Medicare for All’
item.media:description: Proponents held up signs as Senator Bernie Sanders introduced the Medicare for All bill in Washington this month.
item.media:credit: Aaron P. Bernstein/Reuters
item.description: Private insurance pays hospitals much more than the federal government does for patient care. If Medicare for all means Medicare rates, expect an industry backlash.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON

item.title: What They Left Behind: Legacies of the Recently Departed
item.media:description: Mr. Westcott was the only person authorized to carry a camera at the Oak Ridge facilities.
item.media:credit: United States Department of Energy, Oak Ridge
item.description: Some gems from the life’s work of people remembered in obituaries in The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL J. WAKIN
item.category: The Mary Tyler Moore Show (TV Program)

item.title: Gene Wolfe, Acclaimed Science Fiction Writer, Dies at 87
item.media:description: The author Gene Wolfe in an undated photograph. His fellow science fiction writer Neil Gaiman called him “possibly the finest living American writer.”
item.media:credit: Writer Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: His four-book series “The Book of the New Sun” is considered one of the major works of the genre.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GENZLINGER

item.title: Senator McConnell, a Tobacco Ally, Supports Raising Age to Buy Cigarettes
item.media:description: Leading lawmakers are gathering support for legislation at the federal and state levels to curtail sales of tobacco and vaping products to young adults.
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.description: Seeking re-election to a seventh term, the senator cited the rise in teenage vaping as a reason to curtail sales of tobacco and other products.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN

item.title: El Al Airline Warns of Measles After Flight Attendant Falls Into Coma
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.description: The woman was hospitalized after contracting the disease, and passengers on a flight from J.F.K. to Tel Aviv are told to watch for symptoms.
item.dc:creator: KAREN SCHWARTZ
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: This Genetic Mutation Makes People Feel Full — All the Time
item.media:description: Mutations in the MC4R gene usually lead to obesity by preventing a sense of fullness. But one such mutation leaves people uninterested in eating, scientists report.
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.description: Two new studies confirm that weight control is often the result of genetics, not willpower.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Celestial Visions on the Met Roof
item.media:description: For the Met’s Roof Garden Commission, Alicja Kwade created “ParaPivot I” (right) and “ParaPivot II” (left).
item.media:credit: Emily Andrews for The New York Times
item.description: High above Manhattan, Alicja Kwade’s planetary sculpture captures the music of the spheres.
item.dc:creator: JASON FARAGO

item.title: We Asked the 2020 Democrats About Climate Change (Yes, All of Them). Here Are Their Ideas.
item.media:description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand spoke at a rally for the Green New Deal at the Capitol last month.
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: The New York Times sent a climate policy survey to the 18 declared candidates. They all want to stick to the Paris Agreement. Beyond that, they diverge.
item.dc:creator: LISA FRIEDMAN and MAGGIE ASTOR
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: Rites of Passage: ‘Will You Stay With Me Until I Die?’
item.description: My patient had a simple, devastating request. To honor it meant grappling with how a therapist responds to her clients.
item.dc:creator: LORI GOTTLIEB

item.title: Ocean-Clogging Microplastics Also Pollute the Air, Study Finds
item.media:description: A marine biologist specializing in microplastics examined a water sample from the Mediterranean Sea. A new study suggests that the tiny particles also travel by air — and in extraordinary numbers.
item.media:credit: Eric Gaillard/Reuters
item.description: Microplastics are known to cause ocean pollution, but a new study suggests airborne plastic particles pollute the air and dry land as well.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: He Listed a T. Rex Fossil on eBay for $2.95 Million. Scientists Weren’t Thrilled.
item.media:description: Baby Tyrannosaurus rex models at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: “I own this thing,” Alan Detrich recalled telling a museum director. “It is mine. I can do whatever I want.”
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: E.P.A. Moves to ‘Close the Door’ on Asbestos. Consumer Groups Say Loopholes Remain.
item.media:description: Workers spray a house in Detroit, Mich., during demolition to prevent asbestos from becoming airborne.
item.media:credit: Jim West/Science Source
item.description: The new rule will restrict uses of asbestos, a carcinogen, more than initially expected, but health advocates criticized it as falling short of the protections needed.
item.dc:creator: LISA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Dr. Richard Green, 82, Dies; Challenged Psychiatry’s View of Homosexuality
item.media:description: Dr. Richard Green in an undated photo. In 1972, he defied the advice of colleagues and wrote a paper in The International Journal of Psychiatry questioning “the premise that homosexuality is a disease or a homosexual is inferior.”
item.media:credit: via Green Family
item.description: At a time when being gay was classified as a mental disorder, Dr. Green defied the advice of his colleagues and took a professional risk by arguing otherwise.
item.dc:creator: BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: TRENDING: Hotels and Resorts Ramp Up Sustainability Efforts
item.description: For an increasing number of properties, Earth Day is every day.
item.dc:creator: CHARU SURI

item.title: In India, a Renewed Fight Against Leprosy
item.media:description: The hands of Bodhe Annasuya, 45, who acquired leprosy when she was 12 years old. She lives in Balaji Nagar, a leprosy colony, with her husband and adopted son, in Hyderabad, India.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.description: Health workers thought they had vanquished the disease in 2005. But it lived on, cloaked in stigma and medical mystery.
item.dc:creator: APOORVA MANDAVILLI
item.category: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

item.title: Stanford Clears Professor of Helping With Gene-Edited Babies Experiment
item.media:description: Stephen Quake, a professor of biotechnology at Stanford University.
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.description: Stephen Quake and two colleagues were found to have followed proper scientific protocol in their interactions with the Chinese researcher who did the work.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK

item.title: F.D.A. Halts U.S. Sales of Pelvic Mesh, Citing Safety Concerns for Women
item.description: Boston Scientific and Coloplast were the last two companies selling the medical devices, which have resulted in nearly $8 billion in settlements.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Employee Wellness Programs Yield Little Benefit, Study Shows
item.media:description: Researchers followed thousands of BJ’s Wholesale Club employees for a year to monitor the effects of wellness programs. Although many who enrolled in the programs reported exercising more often and eating more healthfully, the study did not find significant medical care savings.
item.media:credit: Mel Evans/Associated Press
item.description: A rigorous new study calls into question whether workplace wellness programs can quickly save employers money on health care bills.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

item.title: Don’t Count on 23andMe to Detect Most Breast Cancer Risks, Study Warns
item.media:description: More than 10 million people have signed up for 23andMe. Many are initially drawn in by ancestry data, but later opt in for health risk tests.
item.media:credit: George Frey/Reuters
item.description: The DNA testing company, which has 10 million customers, misses nearly 90 percent of people with risky BRCA mutations. It says the criticism is overblown.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY
